Understanding Web Accessibility

Published on January 15, 2024

Introduction

Web accessibility ensures that websites and applications are usable by everyone, including people with disabilities. This article covers the fundamentals of creating accessible web content.

Key Principles

The Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) define four main principles:

  • Perceivable - Information must be presentable in ways users can perceive
  • Operable - Interface components must be operable by all users
  • Understandable - Information and operation must be understandable
  • Robust - Content must be robust enough for various assistive technologies

Semantic HTML

Using semantic HTML elements is crucial for accessibility. Elements like <header>, <nav>, <main>, and <footer> provide important context for assistive technologies.

Landmarks

ARIA landmarks help users navigate the page structure. Common landmarks include banner, navigation, main, and contentinfo.

Headings

A proper heading hierarchy (h1-h6) creates a document outline that screen reader users can navigate efficiently.

Forms and Inputs

Form accessibility requires proper labeling and error handling:

Form Element Best Practices
Element Requirement Example
Input Associated label <label for="email">
Button Descriptive text <button>Submit Form</button>
Checkbox Clear label <input type="checkbox"> Accept terms

Conclusion

Accessibility benefits everyone. By following these guidelines, you create more inclusive web experiences.
